head.title: Antarctic Accord Must Protect Environment; Support Gore Plan

hedline.hl1: Antarctic Accord Must Protect Environment; Support Gore Plan

block.p: Deborah Shapley's ''Polar Thinking on the Antarctic'' (Op-Ed, Oct. 17) is as thin in logic as the ozone layer over Antarctica was last month. By contending that research into global warming is threatened by those who seek a ban on development of oil and gas in Antarctica, Ms. Shapley constructs a specious argument that should be iced.

Ms. Shapley extols a pending international minerals agreement that could open the continent to commercial mining as a ''victory for pragmatic diplomacy.'' Yet, if the 22 voting parties approve it, it would be a stunning defeat for the Antarctic environment and its vital role as a global monitoring laboratory. Indeed, if commercial mining ever begins in Antarctica, tanker accidents similar to the Exxon Valdez oil spill disaster in Alaska will be inevitable.

What is most distressing about Ms. Shapley's views is that they are shared by officials within the Bush Administration. The State Department has consistently argued that the United States should ratify the minerals agreement rather than pursue an outright ban. These officials adamantly oppose the efforts of Australia and France to set aside Antarctica as a wilderness reserve where commercial mining is prohibited.

The State Department asserts that the minerals accord would permit any party to veto plans to exploit Antarctica if the environmental risks are too high. The record of other Antarctic agreements, however, indicates that the nations responsible for managing Antarctica have in the past not raised environmental concerns for fear of upsetting delicate political relationships. The same timidity is likely to control decisions about commercial mining.

Fortunately, members of Congress have recognized the fallacies of the Administration's approach. In late September, Senator Albert Gore introduced a resolution that calls upon the United States to negotiate a new agreement to protect Antarctica as a scientific preserve. Until that agreement enters into force, the resolution directs the President not to submit the minerals accord to the Senate for its consent to ratification.

If Ms. Shapley is truly concerned about global warming, she should support the Gore resolution, rather than adoption of the minerals agreement. The fundamental lesson to be learned from global climate change is that we must draw the line on burning of fossil fuels at some point. Given Antarctica's vital role in understanding global warming patterns, the last untouched wilderness is a good place to start. BRUCE S. MANHEIM JR. Washington, Oct. 18, 1989
The writer is a lawyer and scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund's wildlife program.
